events.description: Uranium futures fell from a near two-year high of $101.5 to $92 per pound.
The Uzbek Atomic Energy Agency increased annual production to 7,000 tonnes, exceeding market expectations.
The US government cut regulations on permits and announced $2.7 billion in contracts to secure domestic supply.

facts.fact_text: Uranium futures in the US decreased to $92 per pound from a high of $101.5.

evidences.evidence_text: Uranium futures in the US fell to $92 per pound from the near two-year high of $101.5

facts.fact_text: The Uzbek Atomic Energy Agency produced 7,000 tonnes of Uranium last year.

evidences.evidence_text: The Uzbek Atomic Energy Agency boosted its annual production of Uranium to 7,000 tonnes last year

facts.fact_text: The US government allocated $2.7 billion in contracts to Centrus and other enrichers.

evidences.evidence_text: fresh $2.7 billion in contracts to Centrus and two other reactors and enrichers

facts.fact_text: Cameco approved the development of Westinghouse reactors.

evidences.evidence_text: partnership with Cameco, which approved the development of Westinghouse reactors

claims.claim_text: Increased global supply has temporarily offset the impact of high demand expectations on uranium prices.

evidences.evidence_text: a fresh increase in global supply momentarily outweighed the view of soaring growing demand expectations that carried prices in recent quarters

claims.claim_text: Nuclear power capacity is expected to grow to meet the needs of datacenters and electrification.

evidences.evidence_text: expectations that nuclear power capacity will continue to increase to match datacenter and electrification demand

claims.claim_text: US government contracts are intended to mitigate the loss of nuclear fuel supply from Russia due to sanctions.

evidences.evidence_text: to offset the shun of supply from Russia following sanctions on their nuclear fuel

evidence.evidence_text: a fresh increase in global supply momentarily outweighed the view of soaring growing demand expectations that carried prices in recent quarters
nuclear power capacity will continue to increase to match datacenter and electrification demand
offset the shun of supply from Russia following sanctions on their nuclear fuel
The US government cut regulation on permits for uranium converters and announced deals for the construction of new plants
